alert_summary.description: Extreme cold impacts ongoing in the region; dangerous wind chills may affect Monday morning waiting at bus stops and increase risk of mechanical/transport issues.
Advisories are focused earlier (Friday), not directly on Monday; still indicates active winter pattern with occasional slick travel.
River ice/ice-jam concern through Sunday late morning; not a direct school travel driver unless localized flooding occurs.

meteorology.overall_conditions_summary: For Rockford, MI, the main travel-impacting weather signal for the Monday 2026-01-26 school day is NOT a big snowstorm, but lingering effects from light-to-moderate snow Sunday evening (2026-01-25) plus extreme cold. Sunday’s forecast snowfall is modest (~0.7" total) with light winds (max ~9 mph), which Michigan road crews and schools typically handle easily. The snow also appears to end well before the Monday morning commute (no precip shown overnight into early morning), which favors plowing/road treatment. However, temperatures stay well below freezing (likely single digits to teens) meaning any untreated/slushy spots can refreeze into slick patches—especially on bridges, intersections, and rural roads. Net: snow-day risk for Monday is low based on snow/wind/visibility, but there is a moderate ‘delay/targeted closure’ risk if extreme cold policies are triggered (wind chills around/below ~-10°F at times) or if refreeze creates widespread icy spots.

similar_weather_patterns.pattern_description: Cold, dry high-pressure day followed by light-to-moderate snow showers the evening before school (Sunday night), with limited wind. Typical outcome is plowable/slippery roads but usually not districtwide closure unless snowfall rates spike during the pre-dawn commute.

Very cold air mass already in place (subzero/near-zero mornings) with minor new snow on top of existing pack. Operational impact tends to be more about start-up and bus reliability than snow depth; closures more likely only if wind chills reach roughly -15°F or colder at bus time or if mechanical issues become widespread.

Light freezing rain/ice earlier in the multi-day period, then temperatures stay well below freezing so any untreated slick spots persist. If there is a thin glaze plus any new snow, accident risk rises—this is one of the more common "surprise closure/delay" setups even when snowfall totals are modest.

Advisory-level snow and blowing snow occurring on the prior school day (Friday) can leave residual drifting/rural road issues into Monday only if additional bands continue through the weekend. If bands shut down Saturday, schools typically reopen Monday even with cold.

seasonal_context.typical_conditions_for_date: Late January in west/central Lower Michigan is peak winter operations: frequent subfreezing mornings, established snowpack, and routine plowing/salting. Districts generally stay open with light accumulations; closures are more often driven by ice, whiteout/blizzard conditions, or extreme wind chills (roughly -15°F or colder).
unusual_factors: Multi-day extreme cold episode is underway (warnings/advisories in the region), which increases the operational stress on buses and the likelihood that any earlier slickness does not melt.
Sunday (2026-01-25) forecast shows snow showers and some blowing snow signals in the evening hours, which can matter if it bleeds into late night/pre-dawn Monday.
Temperatures remain well below freezing, so any earlier freezing rain (observed on Friday morning, 2026-01-23) can leave a 'hard base' that becomes hazardous if lightly snow-covered.

local_microclimates: Rockford/northern Kent County can see localized bands and rapidly varying conditions (lake-effect influence), meaning one part of a district may be much worse than another.
Rural/north-of-town roads and open areas are more prone to drifting and re-freeze, even when in-town roads look fine.
infrastructure_considerations: Michigan districts generally plan for snow; plow response is usually sufficient for minor accumulations.
The bigger decision points locally tend to be: untreated back roads, bridge decks, and timing (snow during 5–8 AM bus window) rather than daytime totals.
Extreme cold can create bus starting issues and increases safety concerns at bus stops, but closures typically require very low wind chills rather than just low temperatures.
location_specific_factors.elevation_impact: Rockford area has modest terrain; small elevation changes can still create locally slick hills and shaded areas, but it is not a major mountain-style elevation driver.

history.confidence_assessment: For Monday 2026-01-26, based on the provided Sunday 2026-01-25 forecast, the primary snow-day risk is not total snowfall (forecast snow amount is relatively low), but whether Sunday night snow showers/blowing snow persist into the Monday morning commute and whether any lingering ice from earlier freezing rain becomes snow-covered. With winds not especially strong and no clear signal of a major 8–10+ inch event, a full closure is less likely than a normal open or possibly a delay if roads glaze up or a heavier snow band sets up near daybreak. Overall confidence is medium-low because we do not yet have Monday-specific hourly timing/amounts and school decisions are highly timing-dependent.

safety_recommendations: Primary school-day concern is residual slick spots from Sunday evening snow (starting ~6 PM Sunday, 2026-01-25) combined with very cold pavement temperatures; bridges/overpasses and untreated neighborhood streets are most likely to stay slick into Monday morning (2026-01-26).
Plan for aggressive overnight treatment/plowing on main routes; prioritize bus routes with hills/curves and shaded rural stretches where packed snow can refreeze/harden.
Expect parking lots, sidewalks, and drop-off loops to lag behind road clearing; schedule early lot plowing and apply salt/sand before staff arrival.
Cold morning conditions increase risk of slip/fall for walkers and students at bus stops; ensure extra supervision and request winter traction/appropriate footwear messaging to families.
If snow bands persist later Sunday night than forecast or intensify, re-check conditions by ~5:30–6:00 AM Monday for potential delays rather than full closure.

webWeatherVerifier.verification_summary: For Rockford, MI (ZIP 49341), your WeatherAPI feed shows an extremely low current feels-like of -23.8°F at 9:00 AM local on Fri 2026-01-23 (below the -20°F closure trigger). Weather.com’s Rockford hourly page also shows subzero wind chills (e.g., 'Feels Like -23°' in its hourly list), supporting that dangerously cold air is affecting the area. However, NWS Weather.gov point-forecast pages near Grand Rapids/Kent County show wind chills around -1°F to +1°F at their displayed update times (Thu 2026-01-22 afternoon). That creates a >10°F discrepancy that must be resolved with a same-time, same-location check (ideally a Rockford/49341-specific NWS point forecast and/or observation). Importantly, Monday 2026-01-26 (the school day) is not included in the provided WeatherAPI forecast; the detailed hourly you supplied is for Sunday 2026-01-25, where the lowest hourly feels-like in your data is about -11.3°F (not near -20°F).

final.decision_rationale:
Pre-decision checklist synthesis:
1) Agreement across experts: All teams converge on “not a big snowstorm” for Rockford; the main risk is cold + refreeze/packed snow rather than heavy snow, high wind, or whiteout. Most likely outcome is OPEN, with some chance of a DELAY.
2) Disagreements: The only material conflict was the safety/infrastructure ‘worst conditions until 03:00’ vs the hourly precip ending around 23:00 Sunday. Follow-up resolved this: 03:00 was not supported by the provided hours; worst conditions are better defined as ~18:00–23:00 with a post-snow hazard tail to ~01:00.
3) Plow timing math: Using snow ending ~23:00 Sunday, there are ~7.5 hours until ~06:30 bus rollout and ~8 hours 40 minutes until ~07:40 start—typically enough for trunklines and main arterials. The limiting factor remains neighborhood streets/turnarounds.
4) Ice: No explicit freezing rain signal for Sunday night in the provided forecast (precip type = snow), but ice formation/refreeze risk is elevated due to extreme cold and earlier-period icing context. This raises delay risk more than full-closure risk.
5) Neighboring districts: No confirmed Mon 1/26 closure/delay announcements found on district sites in a targeted scan (Rockford, Forest Hills, Northview, Cedar Springs, Sparta, Lowell, Kent ISD postings). This removes a major upward adjustment.
6) Power outages: Updated snapshot shows very low outages and decreasing trend; no evidence of a power-driven closure.
7) Wind chill verification: Web verification indicates Monday AM feels-like roughly -10 to -19°F, not ≤ -20°F at bus time. The ≤ -20°F value exists in WeatherAPI ‘current’ for Fri 1/23, but that does not automatically carry to Mon 1/26.
8) What would make this wrong: (a) an unforecast lake-effect band persists/redevelops overnight Sun→Mon producing several inches or reducing visibility during 5–8 AM; (b) widespread hidden glaze/black ice forms on secondary roads; (c) a localized outage/heating failure hits one or more schools; (d) Monday wind chill trends colder than expected and crosses ≤ -20°F at bus time.

Weighted decision (per directive): Meteorology (25%) supports low closure risk given <1" and ending before commute; Safety (20%) and Infrastructure (10%) keep risk above ‘near-zero’ due to local streets/turnarounds + refreeze; History (15%) base rates for this pattern are low; News Intel (15%) finds no active Mon closure wave; Power (10%) not a driver; Web verification (5%) removes the ≤ -20°F Monday trigger. Result: 18% probability of a full snow-day closure (higher for a delay than a closure).

alternative_scenarios.scenario: Open on time (most likely): snow ends by ~23:00 Sunday; main routes treated; only isolated slick spots
alternative_scenarios.impact: Normal operations with slower travel on some neighborhood streets; monitor bus stop safety in cold.

alternative_scenarios.scenario: Full closure: overnight lake-effect band overperforms OR widespread hidden ice leads to crash clusters OR unexpected ≤ -20°F wind chills at bus time
alternative_scenarios.impact: Districtwide closure due to unacceptable bus-route safety and/or exposure risk.

for_schools: Plan for NORMAL OPEN with a strong ‘delay-ready’ posture; make the go/no-go call after a 5:30–6:00 AM road check focused on bus turnarounds and known trouble hills.
Prioritize early treatment/plowing for parking lots, sidewalks, drop-off loops; expect chemicals to be less effective in extreme cold—use scraping + sand/traction where needed.
Issue family messaging Sunday evening: expect slick neighborhood streets Monday AM; dress for very cold bus-stop conditions; allow extra commute time.
If you have cold-exposure policy thresholds, reassess wind chill around 5–7 AM Monday using NWS point forecast/observations (not stale cached values).
for_residents: Assume neighborhood streets may be packed/slick Monday morning even if highways look fine; slow down and increase following distance.
Use traction footwear and caution on steps/sidewalks; watch for black ice on bridges and shaded areas.
Prepare for extreme cold at bus stops: cover skin, limit exposure time, and consider rides for younger students if roads are slick.
for_authorities: Overnight: focus traction materials at intersections, hills, bridge decks, and bus-route priority connectors; extreme cold reduces melting benefit.
Ensure plow routing includes key residential bus turnarounds where feasible before 6:30 AM.
If lake-effect bands set up late Sunday night, push targeted alerts quickly to districts and drivers.

positions.rationale: From a meteorology-only perspective, the signal for Monday 2026-01-26 is: light/moderate snow Sunday evening with low winds, then continued bitter cold. That combination typically yields slick spots and slow travel on secondary/local roads Monday morning, but not widespread impassability or whiteout conditions. Because the provided hourly data do not show snow continuing into the Monday pre-dawn/bus window and the forecast totals are under 1 inch, I keep full snow-day probability relatively low. I still elevate above ‘near zero’ because (a) extreme cold reduces treatment effectiveness and preserves hazards, (b) the timing of Sunday evening snow can compact overnight, and (c) lake-effect/local band variability could make pockets worse than the area-average.
keyFactors: Snow amount looks modest for the pre-school window: the only detailed precip you provided (Sun 2026-01-25) totals ~1.7 cm / ~0.7" snow with peak hourly snow around ~1.0 cm (~0.4") and occurs mainly 6–10 PM Sunday, not during the Mon 5–8 AM commute.
Wind/visibility are not classic closure drivers here: max wind ~9 mph and visibility generally ~6 miles; limited blowing/drifting signal (despite some “blowing snow” icons) because winds are light.

Temperatures stay well below freezing (single digits to teens) → high refreeze/packed-snow persistence risk on untreated surfaces (bridges, ramps, neighborhood streets, rural bus routes). This supports “delay risk” more than full closure.

Cold-related operational risk exists but is below typical hard-stop thresholds in the provided Sun-night data: lowest ‘feels like’ in the hourly set is about -11°F, which is uncomfortable but often not enough alone to trigger districtwide closure in West Michigan unless policies/transport constraints are stricter than usual.
Active winter pattern + prior freezing rain mention increases uncertainty: if there’s a thin glaze from earlier icing that becomes snow-covered, crash risk can spike even with small new snow totals.

positions.rationale: Given the pattern (light-to-moderate snow showers Sunday evening, low total accumulation, light winds, persistent cold), the historical base rate for a *full* Monday closure is low, with a more realistic outcome being **open** or **1–2 hour delay** depending on rural road treatment and any hidden ice. I set the snow-day (closure) probability at **18%**—elevated above a typical ‘0.5–1 inch snow’ day because (1) the area is already in a multi-day winter hazard stretch, and (2) hidden ice + powder can create disproportionate morning-commute risk even without big totals.
keyFactors: **Historical closure thresholds vs. this setup:** In west/central Lower Michigan, districtwide closures are historically more tied to (a) significant overnight/early-morning snowfall with poor visibility/drifting, (b) widespread ice, or (c) extreme wind chills at bus-stop time. The Sunday forecast shows *modest* snow (~0.7" total) and light winds (max ~9 mph), which usually points away from a full closure.

**Timing matters more than totals:** The heaviest signal in the provided hourly data is Sunday evening (starting ~6 PM 2026-01-25) rather than a pre-dawn Monday burst. Historically, when snow ends well before the 5–8 AM bus window, districts tend to run (sometimes with a delay).

**Ice “memory” risk from earlier freezing rain:** There is a plausible historical pathway to a surprise closure/delay if Friday’s freezing rain (2026-01-23) left a thin glaze that never gets fully treated, and then Sunday’s light snow hides it. That’s the main historical analog that raises risk above “very low.”

**Cold is operationally stressful but not sufficient by itself:** The extreme cold episode increases the odds of bus-start issues and very slick refreeze on untreated roads. Historically, though, closures are more common when wind chills are closer to ~-15°F or colder during the morning commute. The Sunday-night lowest “feels like” in the provided hourly data is around -11°F, which is more in the “delay possible” band than “closure likely.”

**Local variability / lake-effect corridor risk:** Rockford/northern Kent County can get localized bands. A narrow but intense band setting up late Sunday night into early Monday is the classic way forecasts like this underplay impacts. That tail risk keeps the probability from being single-digits.

positions.rationale: From a safety lens for Rockford, MI for Monday 2026-01-26: I’m expecting *moderate hazard but not widespread impassability*. The forecasted snow Sunday evening (1/25) is enough to create slickness that can persist into Monday morning because of the cold, but the total is relatively low and winds are not strong—so the most likely outcome is ‘open’ or ‘delay’ depending on how well secondary roads and bus turnarounds are treated overnight. I’m putting the full snow-day (closure) probability at 18%—higher than a typical light-snow event because cold + potential hidden ice can produce localized crash clusters, but still below 20% because there’s no strong signal for heavy snow during the Monday morning bus window or significant blowing/whiteout conditions.
keyFactors: Forecast snow amount ahead of Monday looks modest (~0.7" Sunday 1/25), with the heaviest period Sunday evening and no clear pre-dawn/Monday-morning snowfall signal in the provided hourly set—this usually supports an on-time open after overnight plowing.

Primary safety risk is *ice/compaction*, not depth: very cold pavement (single digits/teens) means any slush or earlier glaze won’t melt and can re-freeze, especially on bridges/overpasses, intersections, shaded hills, and untreated neighborhood streets—raising crash risk for buses and teen drivers.

Cold exposure at bus stops is a real safety consideration, but based on the provided Sunday hourly data, wind chills around the commute window look more like ~-5°F to -15°F rather than ≤-20°F; that tends to produce “extra precautions” or a delay in some districts, not an automatic closure.

Infrastructure reality: primary routes likely improve overnight; the limiting factor is uneven conditions on local/residential streets and parking lots/sidewalks at first bell, which tends to push toward delay/targeted route adjustments more than full-district closure.
No power-grid/red-flag operational trigger evident (isolated outages only), so transportation safety remains the main driver.

positions.rationale:
As the news/closure-signal specialist, I weight (1) district communications and (2) whether the broader region is escalating into widespread closures. Right now, the strongest concrete closure signals are backward-looking (Fri 01/23 closures nearby, WMU closures earlier in the week) rather than forward-looking for Mon 01/26. The weather inputs provided for Sun 01/25 point to nuisance-to-minor snow (under 1 inch) and light winds—conditions that usually produce ‘normal operations’ or at most a delay if neighborhood streets are slick.

I land at 18% for a full snow day (closure) on Monday, 2026-01-26. That allows for a realistic tail risk: if Sunday evening snow bands overperform locally, if hidden ice is widespread, if extreme cold/wind chills meet local policy thresholds at bus time, or if operational issues (bus starts, staffing) cascade after several rough days regionally.
keyFactors: No Rockford Public Schools (MI) closure/delay notice found yet for Monday, 2026-01-26 in the district’s own channels (weak ‘official signal’).

Regional disruption context is real (nearby districts had cancellations/closures on Thu 01/22 and Fri 01/23; WMU closed multiple days Jan 20/22/23), but that signal decays fast unless the Monday-specific hazard is comparable.

Forecast signal for the *eve before* school: Sunday 01/25 shows only ~0.68" total snow with light winds (~9 mph max). That is typically ‘manageable’ for West Michigan districts, especially if snow ends before the Monday AM bus window.

Primary risk driver for a closure would be a *non-snow* operational/safety issue: extreme cold policies (wind chills) and refreeze/hidden ice from prior freezing rain + light new snow coating local roads.

WebWeatherVerifier flags major cross-source discrepancies (WeatherAPI vs NWS pages) and that we don’t actually have Monday 01/26 hourly/feels-like in the provided dataset—this uncertainty pushes me away from high probabilities.

debates.topic: Your timing window says worst conditions end around 2026-01-26 03:00 and calls the morning commute impact ‘moderate.’ Meteorologically, the provided dataset doesn’t include Monday-hourly precip/visibility, so that end time could be an assumption. If you have evidence of lingering snow bands after midnight, please specify the meteorological basis (radar trend / additional forecast hours) because it materially changes closure odds.

confidenceJourney.shiftReason: From a meteorology-only perspective, the signal for Monday 2026-01-26 is: light/moderate snow Sunday evening with low winds, then continued bitter cold. That combination typically yields slick spots and slow travel on secondary/local roads Monday morning, but not widespread impassability or whiteout conditions. Because the provided hourly data do not show snow continuing into the Monday pre-dawn/bus window and the forecast totals are under 1 inch, I keep full snow-day probability relatively low. I still elevate above ‘near zero’ because (a) extreme cold reduces treatment effectiveness and preserves hazards, (b) the timing of Sunday evening snow can compact overnight, and (c) lake-effect/local band variability could make pockets worse than the area-average.

Given the pattern (light-to-moderate snow showers Sunday evening, low total accumulation, light winds, persistent cold), the historical base rate for a *full* Monday closure is low, with a more realistic outcome being **open** or **1–2 hour delay** depending on rural road treatment and any hidden ice. I set the snow-day (closure) probability at **18%**—elevated above a typical ‘0.5–1 inch snow’ day because (1) the area is already in a multi-day winter hazard stretch, and (2) hidden ice + powder can create disproportionate morning-commute risk even without big totals.

From a safety lens for Rockford, MI for Monday 2026-01-26: I’m expecting *moderate hazard but not widespread impassability*. The forecasted snow Sunday evening (1/25) is enough to create slickness that can persist into Monday morning because of the cold, but the total is relatively low and winds are not strong—so the most likely outcome is ‘open’ or ‘delay’ depending on how well secondary roads and bus turnarounds are treated overnight. I’m putting the full snow-day (closure) probability at 18%—higher than a typical light-snow event because cold + potential hidden ice can produce localized crash clusters, but still below 20% because there’s no strong signal for heavy snow during the Monday morning bus window or significant blowing/whiteout conditions.

As the news/closure-signal specialist, I weight (1) district communications and (2) whether the broader region is escalating into widespread closures. Right now, the strongest concrete closure signals are backward-looking (Fri 01/23 closures nearby, WMU closures earlier in the week) rather than forward-looking for Mon 01/26. The weather inputs provided for Sun 01/25 point to nuisance-to-minor snow (under 1 inch) and light winds—conditions that usually produce ‘normal operations’ or at most a delay if neighborhood streets are slick.

I land at 18% for a full snow day (closure) on Monday, 2026-01-26. That allows for a realistic tail risk: if Sunday evening snow bands overperform locally, if hidden ice is widespread, if extreme cold/wind chills meet local policy thresholds at bus time, or if operational issues (bus starts, staffing) cascade after several rough days regionally.

alert.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued January 22 at 11:14AM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.areas: Allegan, MI; Barry, MI; Calhoun, MI; Clare, MI; Clinton, MI; Eaton, MI; Gratiot, MI; Ingham, MI; Ionia, MI; Isabella, MI; Jackson, MI; Kalamazoo, MI; Kent, MI; Lake, MI; Mason, MI; Mecosta, MI; Montcalm, MI; Muskegon, MI; Newaygo, MI; Oceana, MI; Osceola, MI; Ottawa, MI; Van Buren, MI
alert.desc:
ESFGRR

Bitterly cold temperatures moving into Michigan over the next few
days will increase the risk of ice jams on rivers. While many
locations have already frozen over, ongoing ice growth will continue
to increase in any open water areas.

These temperatures have not been seen for many years in West
Michigan, which means that some areas that don't typically
experience river ice jams may have issues this year. Ice jams can
result in water levels rising much more quickly than usual, which
can catch people off guard. Anyone living or working near rivers in
West Michigan should prepare now for potential river ice and rising
water levels.

While temperatures warm up a bit early next week, this overall cold
weather pattern will continue through at least next week, which will
keep ice locked in place on the rivers.


You can always find the latest river level information at water.noaa.
gov

alert.headline: Extreme Cold Warning issued January 22 at 9:21PM EST until January 24 at 11:00AM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.areas: Mason; Lake; Osceola; Clare; Oceana; Newaygo; Mecosta; Isabella; Muskegon; Montcalm; Gratiot; Ottawa; Kent; Ionia; Clinton
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Dangerously cold wind chills as low as 32 below.

* WHERE...Portions of central, south central, southwest, and west
central Michigan.

* WHEN...Until 11 AM EST Saturday.

* IMPACTS...The dangerously cold wind chills as low as 30 below zero
could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as 10 minutes.
Frostbite and hypothermia will occur if unprotected skin is
exposed to these temperatures. An extended period of freezing
temperatures could cause ruptured water pipes.
alert.instruction:
Avoid outside activities if possible. When outside, make sure you
wear appropriate clothing, a hat, and gloves.

alert.headline: Winter Weather Advisory issued January 22 at 9:21PM EST until January 23 at 1:00PM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.areas: Mason; Lake; Oceana; Newaygo; Muskegon; Ottawa; Kent; Allegan; Barry; Van Buren; Kalamazoo
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Snow and blowing snow. Additional snow accumulations
between 2 and 5 inches. Winds gusting as high as 35 mph.

* WHERE...Portions of southwest and west central Michigan.

* WHEN...Until 1 PM EST Friday.

* IMPACTS...Roads, and especially bridges and overpasses, will
likely become slick and hazardous. Visibility and road conditions
may change rapidly over short distances in lake effect snow. Plan
on slippery road conditions. The hazardous conditions could impact
the Friday morning commute.
alert.instruction:
Slow down and use caution while traveling.

During lake effect snow, the weather can vary from bands of locally
heavy snow to dry weather just a few miles away. Visibilities can
also vary greatly. Be prepared for rapid changes in weather,
visibility, and road conditions.

alert.headline: Extreme Cold Warning issued January 23 at 3:47AM EST until January 24 at 11:00AM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.areas: Mason; Lake; Osceola; Clare; Oceana; Newaygo; Mecosta; Isabella; Muskegon; Montcalm; Gratiot; Ottawa; Kent; Ionia; Clinton
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Dangerously cold wind chills as low as 25 to 30 below.

* WHERE...Portions of central, south central, southwest, and west
central Michigan.

* WHEN...Until 11 AM EST Saturday.

* IMPACTS...These dangerously cold wind chills could cause frostbite
on exposed skin in 30 minutes or less. Frostbite and hypothermia
will occur if unprotected skin is exposed to these temperatures.
An extended period of freezing temperatures could cause ruptured
water pipes.
alert.instruction:
Avoid outside activities if possible. When outside, make sure you
wear appropriate clothing, a hat, and gloves. Keep pets indoors as
much as possible. Considering checking in on older family, friends,
and neighbors. Ensure portable heaters are used correctly. Do not
use generators or grills inside.

alert.headline: Winter Weather Advisory issued January 23 at 3:29AM EST until January 23 at 7:00PM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.areas: Mason; Lake; Oceana; Newaygo; Muskegon; Ottawa; Kent; Allegan; Barry; Van Buren; Kalamazoo
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Snow. Additional snow accumulations up to two inches near
the lakeshore. Very poor visibilities in falling and blowing snow.

* WHERE...Portions of southwest and west central Michigan.

* WHEN...Until 7 PM EST this evening.

* IMPACTS...Roads, and especially bridges and overpasses, will
likely be slick and hazardous. Visibility and road conditions may
change rapidly over short distances in lake effect snow. The
hazardous conditions are expected to impact the Friday morning and
evening commutes.
alert.instruction:
Slow down and use caution while traveling.

During lake effect snow, the weather can vary from bands of locally
heavy snow to dry weather just a few miles away. Visibilities can
also vary greatly. Be prepared for rapid changes in weather,
visibility, and road conditions.
